sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• a 5-day and a 10-day sulfADIAZINE desensitization regimens in AIDS patients has been presented
  • Acute otitis media, Due to Haemophilus influenzae, in combination with penicillin: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Acute otitis media, Due to Haemophilus influenzae, in combination with penicillin: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Chancroid: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Chancroid: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Haemophilus influenzae meningitis, In combination with parenteral streptomycin; Adjunct: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Haemophilus influenzae meningitis, In combination with parenteral streptomycin; Adjunct: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • HIV infection - Toxoplasmosis; Prophylaxis: secondary prophylaxis (preferred regimen), 2000 to 4000 mg ORALLY daily in 2 to 4 divided doses plus pyrimethamine 25 to 50 mg ORALLY daily plus leucovorin 10 to 25 mg ORALLY daily
  • HIV infection - Toxoplasmosis; Prophylaxis: secondary prophylaxis (alternative regimen), 2000 to 4000 mg ORALLY daily in 2 to 4 divided doses plus atovaquone 750 mg ORALLY every 6 to 12 hour
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Inclusion conjunctivitis: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Malaria, due to chloroquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum; Adjunct: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Malaria, due to chloroquine-resistant strains of Plasmodium falciparum; Adjunct: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Meningococcal meningitis; Treatment and Prophylaxis: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Meningococcal meningitis; Treatment and Prophylaxis: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Nocardiosis: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Nocardiosis: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Rheumatic fever, Recurrent; Prophylaxis: (greater than 27 kg) 1 g ORALLY once a day; (27 kg or less) 500 mg ORALLY once a day (guideline dosing)
  • Rheumatic fever, Recurrent; Prophylaxis: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY (manufacturer dosing)
  • Rheumatic fever, Recurrent; Prophylaxis: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours (manufacturer dosing)
  • Toxoplasma encephalitis: (with/without HIV) initial 2 to 4 g ORALLY (manufacturer dosing)

  • Toxoplasma encephalitis: (HIV) preferred therapy (less than 60 kg), 1000 mg ORALLY every 6 hour plus pyrimethamine 200 mg ORALLY for 1 dose, then 50 mg ORALLY daily plus leucovorin 10 to 25 mg (can increase to 50 mg) ORALLY daily for at least 6 week (guideline dosing)
  • Toxoplasma encephalitis: (HIV) preferred therapy (60 kg or greater), 1500 mg ORALLY every 6 hour plus pyrimethamine 200 mg ORALLY for 1 dose, then 75 mg ORALLY daily plus leucovorin 10 to 25 mg (can increase to 50 mg) ORALLY daily for at least 6 week (guideline dosing)
  • Toxoplasma encephalitis: (HIV) alternative therapy, 1000 to 1500 mg ORALLY every 6 hour plus atovaquone 1500 mg orally twice daily for at least 6 week (guideline dosing)
  • Trachoma: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Trachoma: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: initial, 2 to 4 g ORALLY
  • Urinary tract infectious disease: maintenance, 2 to 4 g ORALLY divided into 3 to 6 doses, every 24 hours

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: use caution
  • hepatic impairment: use caution
  • dosing by blood levels: most infections, 5 to 15 mg/100 mL (free sulfonamide); serious infections, 12 to 15 mg/100 mL (free sulfonamide); maximum levels, 20 mg/100 mL (total sulfonamide)
  • protein calorie malnutrition (pediatrics): reduce the dose or prolong the dosing schedule due to increased exposure

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to sulfADIAZINE or other sulfonamides
  • infants less than 2 months (except congenital toxoplasmosis)
  • pregnant women at term
  • breast feeding

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• impaired renal or hepatic function
  • patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• WHO: Avoid breastfeeding.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal pain, Diarrhea, Nausea, Vomiting
Serious
  • Dermatologic:Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Hematologic:Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia, Hemolytic anemia, Leukopenia, Thrombocytopenia
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis, Hypersensitivity reaction
  • Renal:Crystalluria

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: SulfADIAZINE is a antibacterial agent of the sulfonamide class. SulfADIAZINE exerts antibacterial activity by competitive inhibition of bacterial synthesis of folic acid (pteroylglutamic acid) from aminobenzoic acid

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, Oral: 4 hours
  • Bioavailability, Oral: well absorbed from gastrointestinal tract

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Bile: Minor amount, % changed unknown
  • Renal: Extensive, 15% to 40% changed
  • Renal clearance: 0.55 mL/min/kg

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Oral
take each oral dose with 8 ounces of water and consume additional water at frequent intervals throughout the day

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• free sulfonamide blood levels; range, 5 to 15 mg/100 mL may be indicative of efficacy for most infections
  • free sulfonamide blood levels; range, 12 to 15 mg/100 mL may be indicative of efficacy for serious infections
  • serum sulfADIAZINE levels; periodically in patients with serious infections
  • resolution of sign and symptoms of infection may be indicative of efficacy
  • total serum sulfonamide levels; 20 mg/100 mL may be indicative of toxicity
  • CBC; frequently during treatment
  • urinalysis with microscopic examination; frequently during treatment

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
OVERDOSE: Data limited. Effects may be an extension of adverse events reported with sulfonamides. Methemoglbinemia has been reported after overdose. ADVERSE EVENTS: Adverse reactions to sulfonamides can involve nearly every organ system; many effects appear to be hypersensitivity reactions, and are dose related. DERMATOLOGIC: Various dermatological reactions, including rash, pruritus, erythema nodosum, and quite severe and often fatal erythema multiforme of the Stevens-Johnson type have been reported. Lyell's Syndromes are usually associated with the use of a long-acting sulfonamides. GASTROINTESTINAL: Nausea and vomiting are common. HYPERSENSITIVITY REACTION: Transient myopia, conjunctivitis, hepatic injury, and keratitis may occur in association with a hypersensitivity reaction. NEUROLOGIC: Headache, depression, and hallucinations have been reported with therapy.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
  • Decontamination: Activated charcoal.
  • Support: Treatment is symptomatic and supportive.
  • Hypersensitivity reaction: For signs and symptoms of anaphylaxis administer oxygen, establish an airway, and give epinephrine and diphenhydramine as indicated.
  • Hypotensive episode: IV isotonic fluids at 10 to 20 mL/kg, dopamine, norepinephrine.
  • Methemoglobinemia: Obtain a methemoglobin level. Treat symptomatic methemoglobinemia (usually at methemoglobin levels above 20% to 30%) with methylene blue and oxygen therapy.
  • Seizure: Seizures have been reported infrequently. Give benzodiazepines, barbiturates as indicated.
  • Monitoring of patient: Obtain a baseline CBC, electrolytes including glucose level and hepatic enzymes and renal function tests.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
SULFONAMIDES
TOXICITY: Methemoglobinemia has been reported after ingestion of 15 g sulfamethoxazole. Many of the adverse effects related to sulfonamides are hypersensitivity reactions, that develop at therapeutic doses. The incidence of adverse effects increases with higher doses. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Varies by agent.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause diarrhea or nausea.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of blood dyscrasia such as unusual bruising/bleeding, rash, fever, or sore throat.
  • Advise patient to maintain adequate hydration during therapy to prevent crystalluria and formation of renal stones.
